conversation.content: [nervous] Eh, no estaba segura de que fueras a, bueno, presentarte de verdad ya que, [shaky voice], o sea, las funcionarias no suelen visitar a sus antiguas reclusas.

[warm] Mira, llevo siendo funcionaria de prisiones, [slowly], quince años y nunca, [hesitantly], he visitado a nadie después de su puesta en libertad, pero claro tampoco había, [very quietly], sacado a nadie de una celda en llamas antes.

[sincere] Bueno, eh, cuando me sacaste arrastrando por aquel, [frustrated], pasillo lleno de humo mientras todas las demás, [anxious], corrían en dirección contraria, o sea, podrías haberme, [trailing off], dejado allí como decía el protocolo...
[bold] El protocolo no significa mucho cuando alguien está, [passionately], gritando pidiendo ayuda detrás de una puerta de celda atascada. [pause]
[sincere] Eh, mi hija no para de preguntar por, pues, la señora que, [crying while speaking], salvó la vida de papá, y esto, no sé cómo, [whispering], explicarle que eras mi funcionaria.
[empathetically] Bueno, eh, quizá podrías decirle simplemente que, [gently], a veces la gente se conoce en circunstancias complicadas, ¿sabes?
Tenías quemaduras de segundo grado en los, [angry], brazos por forzar aquella puerta y aun así volviste, [loudly], a entrar por tres tíos más. [sigh]
O sea, eh, esas cicatrices me recuerdan que, [proud], ser funcionaria no es solo cerrar puertas, pues. [laugh]
[relieved] Las pesadillas sobre aquel incendio pararon cuando, [trembling], me enteré de que habías salido bien de la operación y que, [very melancholic], volverías al trabajo.

[curious] Eh, ¿cómo te enteraste siquiera de mi operación si, bueno, [confused], ya te habían trasladado al régimen abierto para entonces y, [whispering loudly], se supone que las reclusas no pueden acceder a esa información, esto?
[bitter] Las noticias vuelan.

[witty] El cotilleo carcelario es más fiable que, [animated], las noticias a veces, especialmente cuando se trata de, [chuckle], funcionarias que rompen el protocolo para salvar vidas en vez de, [mockingly], seguir los procedimientos de evacuación.
[apologetic] Mira, eh, sé que no fui exactamente, [regretful], la reclusa modelo durante esos tres años, ¿sabes?
Bueno, eh, una vez me tiraste una bandeja de comida y, [playful], me llamaste cosas bastante creativas, pero o sea, [cheerful], también enseñaste a leer a media galería, esto.
Lo de la bandeja fue antes de, [embarrassed], saber que te habías presentado voluntaria para dirigir el programa de alfabetización. [groan]

[formal] La directora dijo que visitarte podría ser, [stern], inapropiado dada nuestra historia, pero salvar la vida de alguien crea, [emotionally], un vínculo diferente que trasciende esas, [clearing throat], barreras institucionales.
Un vínculo diferente.
Mi psicóloga dice que tengo, [anxiously], culpa de superviviente por las dos reclusas a las que no pudimos llegar a tiempo.

[very sincerely] Entraste corriendo en un infierno literal mientras otras funcionarias, [furious], se quedaron fuera esperando a los bomberos, ¿y de alguna forma crees que, [shouting], no hiciste suficiente?

[exhausted] Todavía me despierto algunas noches, [gasping], oliendo aquel humo y oyendo aquellas alarmas, entonces recuerdo, [relieved], verte respirando cuando salimos y eso me ayuda a, [very slowly], volver a dormirme. [deep breath]

original_conversation.content: [nervous] Um, I wasn't sure if you'd, well, actually show up since, [shaky voice], I mean, guards don't usually visit their former inmates.

[warm] You know, I've been a corrections officer for, [slowly], fifteen years and I've never once, [hesitantly], visited someone after release, but then again I've never, [very quietly], pulled someone out of a burning cell before.

Well, umm, when you dragged me through that, [frustrated], smoke-filled hallway while everyone else was, [anxious], running the other way, I mean, you could've just, [trailing off], left me there like protocol said...
[bold] Protocol doesn't mean much when someone's, [passionately], screaming for help behind a jammed cell door. [pause]
[sincere] Um, my daughter keeps asking about, well, the lady who, [crying while speaking], saved daddy's life, and er, I don't know how to, [whispering], explain that you were my guard.
[empathetically] Well, um, maybe you could just tell her that, [gently], sometimes people meet in complicated circumstances, you know?
You had second-degree burns on your, [angry], arms from prying that door open and still went, [loudly], back for three more guys. [sigh]
I mean, umm, those scars remind me that, [proud], being a CO isn't just about locking doors, well. [laugh]
[relieved] The nightmares about that fire stopped when I, [trembling], heard you made it through surgery okay and were, [very melancholic], coming back to work.

[curious] Um, how did you even know about my surgery since, well, [confused], you were already transferred to minimum security by then and, [whispering loudly], inmates aren't supposed to get that information, er?
[bitter] Word travels.

[witty] The prison grapevine is more reliable than, [animated], CNN sometimes, especially when it comes to, [chuckle], guards who break protocol to save lives instead of, [mockingly], following evacuation procedures.
[apologetic] Look, umm, I know I wasn't exactly, [regretful], the model prisoner during those three years, you know.
Well, um, you threw a food tray at me once and, [playful], called me some pretty creative names, but I mean, [cheerful], you also taught half the block to read, er.
That food tray thing was before I, [embarrassed], knew you volunteered to run the literacy program. [groan]

[formal] The warden said visiting you might be, [stern], inappropriate given our history, but saving someone's life creates, [emotionally], a different kind of bond that transcends those, [clearing throat], institutional boundaries.
Different kind of bond.
My therapist says I have, [anxiously], survivor's guilt about the two inmates we couldn't reach in time.
[very sincerely] You ran into a literal inferno while other COs, [furious], stood outside waiting for fire crews, and somehow you think you, [shouting], didn't do enough?

[exhausted] I still wake up some nights, [gasping], smelling that smoke and hearing those alarms, then I remember, [relieved], seeing you breathing when we made it outside and it helps me, [very slowly], fall back asleep. [deep breath]

scenario: A corrections officer visits the former inmate she helped evacuate during a prison fire six months ago, who credits her with saving his life despite their complicated past as guard and prisoner.
